data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A movable structure used to close off an entrance, typically consisting of a panel that swings on hinges or that slides or rotates.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A similar part on a piece of furniture or a vehicle.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The room or building to which a door belongs.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: They live three doors down the hall.

data.text: A means of approach or access.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: looking for the door to success.

data.text: To strike (a passing bicyclist, for example) by suddenly opening a vehicular door.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To serve as a doorman or doorwoman of (a nightclub, for example).
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: (at (someone's) door) As a charge holding someone responsible.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: You shouldn't lay the blame for the fiasco at her door.

data.text: (close/shut) To refuse to allow for the possibility of.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: The secretary of state closed the door on future negotiations.
